Until today, Empyrion was in Early Access for five years, and I suspect it will remain in an EA state for years more, if not perpetually.

I've reached high-tier survival maybe a handful of times in all the years I've played this title, with most of my 600+ hours having gone into early to mid-game efforts whenever a new alpha drops. That's not to say I don't play for fun. I do, almost exclusively, and I wouldn't keep checking in if I thought Empyrion sucked completely. FWIW, the building system is engaging, and exploration can be loads of fun in co-op.

However, there's a notion going around that players are somehow unreasonable when they're critical of Eleon Game Studios or the game after X number of hours played.

A certain fanboy/moderator would apparently have everyone believe that his own 16,000 hours played is somehow reflective of the immense quality of this game, and anyone who has hundreds or thousands of hours is in fact a living testimony to Eleon Game Studios' unrivaled greatness.

Meanwhile, in the real world, Empyrion is clunky, bug-ridden, amateurish and frustrating even at its best.

I'm usually fine with that. Kenshi is one of my favorite games of all time, after all. But "You played X hours and got your money's worth, so shut up," is not an argument. 

Version 1.0 is not a complete game, and shouldn't be portrayed as such through deliberately confusing manipulations of common game dev nomenclature.

However, if "shut up" is the official fanboy/moderator/developer position, then my official position is a negative review, and a strong recommendation to look elsewhere for sci-fi survival.

Few similar games do as much as Empyrion on such a massive scale, but nearly every game I can think of does what it does, within its own scope, better than Empyrion.

- The first-person mechanics are perhaps the worst I've ever seen. Playing Empyrion doesn't feel like moving around as a character, but rather gives me the sense of a camera on wheels. Animations are ugly or nonexistent for basic tasks. It would've been a damn shame twenty years ago. Today it's inexcusable.

- Characters are hideous and hideously animated. Despite the first-person woes, don't even think about playing this in third-person.

- Combat is an uninspired, impact-lacking mess. Weapons feel like BB guns, and even saying that feels like an undeserved insult to air rifles. If there's one single gameplay element that kills my Empyrion joy faster than any other, it's the awful, pea-shooter combat. This is unforgivable, because combat is central to the game unless you're only in it for creative mode.

- The AI is rock-stupid and blatantly plays by different rules. Enemies can magically "hack" (take over) your base from long range if they can't reach your core, and their base and ship weapons are superior to player weapons in almost every way. Fighting against NPCs is essentially a matter of learning how to cheese. Recent attempts to create end game content have exacerbated this problem.

- Unity Store assets are still commonplace. I mean ... whatever, I guess. I couldn't afford to make my own game assets, either.

- Physics—what physics?

- Flight model—what flight model?

(It's been brought to my attention that I should point out there technically is a so-called flight model. Sadly, there's no real sense of mass or weight. Never was, and neither the "flight model" nor atmospheric engines that were added with it changed this. The same floating camera phenomenon that applies to walking/running also applies to every class of vehicle. I say this as a flight sim fan who thinks Space Engineers and No Man's Sky both did a decent fakery job with flight, and I would have been fine with something similar in Empyrion.)

- Bugs. Everywhere. Various systems are glitchy.

- No volumetric water. Dug a hole at the bottom of a lake? Congratulations, you've made a permanent air pocket that you can build on and live in just like on dry land. This also means you can't create a Minecraft-style backyard pond, or build a Subnautica-style underwater home. I mean, you *can* build underwater, but it's just depressing.

- Canned environmental sounds, probably from the Unity Store (I can't confirm this). It's weird to be on a completely alien planet, but hear crickets and howling wolves.

This is all stuff one would expect of an ALPHA product, of course.

If you just want to build stuff or walk around on some same-y alien worlds, it's hard to say Empyrion isn't worth twenty bucks. It's huge with lots of moving parts. If you're looking for a deep game with polished (or even competent) survival and action mechanics, investing time in Empyrion might leave you some combination of irritated, bored and sad.

Review subject to change, but I wouldn't bet on it.

Сначала эмоции: Да это же круто! Я могу сконструировать ховер, малый разведчик-истребитель или просто титанических размеров космолёт, а также жилую базу на планете или в комосе! И всё это с огромным количеством комбинаций блоков и модулей, дай только волю воображению! В игре есть всё что нужно авантюристам-выживальщикам: физика, невероятные творческие возможности в постройке и конструировании, сюжет, различные ресурсы...
Ну а теперь по существу:
Сюжет есть, спойлерить не буду. Это, конечно же, это не глубоко проработанная вселенная Mass Effect с длительным детальным повествованием, но приятно его наличие. Хотя тут сюжет не главная фишка игры.
А главная фишка - креатив, основанный на комбинации различный блоков. При конструировании учитывается центр масс, направление и мощность стабилизирующих, подъёмных и тяговых двигателей, с недавнего времени с усложнением конструкции необходимо наращивание вычислительной мощности центрального компьютера управления, будь это база или транспортное средство. Если хорошо разобраться с комбинированием блоков и модулей различной формы и назначения - можно делать обалденые вещи.
Что мне лично хочется от игры в будущем: 
1) Лучше оптимизация. Разработчики работают над этим регулярно, фреймрейт становится выше и стабильнее, реально молодцы, осталось ещё чуть-чуть)))
2) Очень не хватает физики столкновений. В бою блоки деформируются, повреждённые модули также заметно влияют на функционирование конструкции (если вы недальновидно выставили красиво светящийся генератор наружу корпуса, чтобы выпендриться перед девчонками, то будьте готовы получить снаряд в эту уязвимую точку и с отказавшими системами, в т.ч. орудиями и силовой установкой, зависнуть в космосе, ожидая дальнейшего расстрела или неприлично жёстко приземлиться на поверхность планеты с таким же неприятным исходом...). Повреждения имеют разные степени тяжести, отражаемые на внешнем виде повреждённой части. Но всё же когда огромный космолёт массой несколько килотонн впиливается в астероид на скорости 100 м/с и у него даже мордашка не поцарапалась - возникает стойкое ощущение нехватки реализма в этом вопросе...
3) Большего разнообразия НПС и мобов. Стоит пояснить, что и сейчас грех жаловаться на отсутствие заселённости миров, просто хочется видеть больше уникальный зверей на планетах с разным климатом и, было бы очень круто, больше неигровых космических фракций со своими квестами.

Что может помочь новичку:
1) Поскорее выполните доступные квесты фракции Полярис и продавайте им оружие (хорошо идут штурмовые и снайперские винтовки, хотя и пистолеты с дробовиками сойдут), это поможет иметь деньги, на которые можно покупать недоступный на планете, но нужный вам материал для крафта. Также экзотическую руду в малых количествах можно достать из агрессивных големов, обитающих в пустыне и на снежных равнинах, чаще по ночам. Для безопасного их препарирования лучше всего подойдёт снайперская винтовка, несколько выстрелов в голову - проблемы нет, лут есть.
2) Не вся живность агрессивна. Например, я поначалу стрелял в пустынных червей, едва завидев их (уж больно рожа страшная), а потом понял, что если я не атакую, они очень миролюбивы (на лицо ужасные, добрые внутри, там живут несчастные черви-дикари...).
3) Не лезьте в большие заброшенные шахты, если не обзавелись штурмовой, а лучше импульсной винтовкой, ещё лучше захватить гранатомёт. Из медикаментов обязательно взять минимум 2-3 бинта и средство от паразитов.
4) Пистолет, по моему скромному мнению, есть самое бесполезное оружие, годное только для продажи. У стартового инструмента выживальщика в режиме огня пистолет выгодно отличается лишь дистанцией, а огневая мощь такая же, если не хуже...
5) Лучше всего собирать протеин для переработки в высокоеффективные питательные батончики в глубоких озёрах на дне, там растёт много протеиновых водорослей, а также тех, что являются источником плазмы, необходимой для создания медикаментов. Так можно набрать достаточно много, потратив меньше времени, и что более важно, кислорода.
Ладно, об остальном лучше как-нибудь гайд написать будет.

Выводы: Игру однозначно стоит брать, уже сейчас она составляет серьёзную конкуренцию подобным проектам, предлагая более широкие геймплейные возможности. Мне лично она нравится больше всех из этого направления. Разработчики её не бросают, реально улучшая с каждым патчем своё творение. Когда она дойдёт до полноценного релиза, уверен, это будет чуть ли не самая лучшая игра-песочница про космос с сюжетом, квестами, караванами, блекджеком и инопланетянками.

72731292.review:
Bon cela fait longtemps que je n'avais pas fait de critique sur un jeu. 

Adepte de jeu de survie (ARK, 7d2d, No Man's sky etc...) J'ai voulu tester Empyrion car il me semblait relativement complet (Enfin) pour un jeu de survie spatial. En gros, ce jeu est un mix entre No Man's sky, Avorion, Space Engineers et Ark (pour les maladies/froids etc...)

Graphismes et physique du jeu:
Le jeu, bien qu'en alpha, est relativement beau. les effets de lumières et d'ombres sont soignés et on peut dire que la direction artistique de l'espace est bien maîtrisée. En ce qui concerne les bloque et les objets, on retrouve une palette de choix assez varié pour fabriquer son/sa propre vaisseau/base qui sera unique. Je n'ai pas de patience pour les construction bien compliquées mais le workshop est rempli de créations magnifiques réalisées par des gens qui ont beaucoup plus de temps libre que moi.
La physique du jeu me rappelle 7d2d en un peu moins bien. On a la gravité à prendre en comptre, l'intégrité des structures etc. Mais il manque encore un certains réalisme. Certains bugs envoient un bloc de plusieurs tonne en l'air comme s'il pesait 5 kg. Les accélérations des vaisseaux peuvent être trop importantes si bien qu'on dirait que vos créations pèsent le poids d'une trotinette. Enfin, le personnage a tendance à glisser sur tout ce qui existe ce qui est assez frustrant pour les phases de construction.

Crafting/construction:
La partie fun de ce jeu. Ayant joué à Avorion (que je recommande aussi d'ailleurs), j'ai eu plaisir à crafter mes vaisseaux/bases sur ce jeu. MAIS ! Ce n'est pas facile de prendre en main ce système. beaucoup seront frustrés au début de devoir faire des rotations d'objets (surtout les coins de fenêtres pour les cockpits aaargh...) mais encore une fois, il s'agit d'avoir de la patience car malgré un jeu en alpha, beaucoup d'éléments sont à disposition afin de faire de très belles créations, même pour des gens avec aucun talent comme votre serviteur.
J'aime beaucoup le système de carburant, d'O² à gérer pour les structures ainsi que la possibilité de créer un système de défense pour ces bases (que je détaillerai dans la partie Gameplay). 
Les ressources semblent compliquées à récupérer au début mais tout devient plus simple dès que vous avez accès au Prométium et à l'outil multifonction +foreuse et ensuite miner et farmer devient très plaisant, et surtout pas trop long !
Bémol: j'ai personellement  un problème avec le drone (F5) pour la construction, trop d'inertie dans les mouvements ça devient vite agaçant. De plus, je ne joue pas avec le CPU que je trouve bien trop restrictif en terme de construction (un vaisseau T2 ne peut pas avoir de bouclier ou tout juste) sachant que pour les combats, il vaut mieux être très bien armé ET avoir du bouclier sous peine de se faire oneshot par les tourelles ennemies.

Gameplay:
Que dire ? Il y a tous les aspects que j'aimerai voir dans ce type de jeu. Pas assez développé certes, mais pour le moment, il y a tout. 
-Différentes factions dans la galaxie: check
-Interactions avec les factions avec un système de réput: Check
-Quêtes chez toutes les factions: check même si très peu nombreuses:
-Commerces: Check même si très peu developpé pour le moment
Les factions hostiles viendront lancer des raids chez vous: check et c'est fun au début, un peu trop simple quand vous avez vos tourelles construites mais j'ai pas testé le mode hard core pour voir si ça augmente le nombre d'ennemis
-Galaxie générée de manière procédurale
-Des planètes assez vivantes avec des patrouilles de soldats de différentes factions de temps à autre
-Possibilité d'être un pirate: check
-Possibilité de contruire une station spatiale: check
-La faim, le froid, le chaud, l'hermétisation, la gestion des flux d'air, les meubles, la cuisine, l'horticulture, il manquerait plus que l'élevage et on a tout ce qu'il faut !

Bémol: Les PnJs sont très très très très....Alpha quoi, l'IA est médiocre, les gestes sont dignes de playmobiles et c'est en gros le gros point négatif du jeu, on y croit presque mais pas encore. Mais je pense que ça va s'améliorer avec le temps

Conclusion:
Empyrion me satisfait amplement pour le jeu qu'il est en ce moment. Et on voit très bien le potentiel qu'il peut avoir dans quelques temps. J'étais frustré de NMS caar je ne pouvait pas créer MON vaisseau, frustré d'Avorion et d'Elite dangerous car je ne pouvait pas en descendre, de Star Citizen car...voila.
Si vous aimez la survie, le crafting personnalisé et l'exploration, ce jeu est fait pour vous, acheté en promo pour 15 euros, c'est un bon investissement pour le jeu qu'il pourrait devenir !

-If you can't figure something out, look at the controls. Notably, jetpack toggle is 'J', warp drive is 'K', and save blueprint is alt+O. These are important when you find yourself floating helplessly through space without knowing why, want to travel to a different planet, or when you design a ship in creative mode to recreate in survival mode. The first two, at least, could be easily alleviated by some contextual on-screen tips, and that's the sort of thing that contributes to feeling more like a beta than a release product.

-Also, pause is, uh... pause. You know, that key you forget is even on your keyboard. The game won't pause without it.

-You can't swim with a weapon or tool in your hands. So when you sink like a stone and can't figure out how to get back to the surface, just hit '0' to switch to empty hands and you'll magically begin swimming. Again, contextual tips could really help here.

-Radiation is never really explained. As far as I can understand it, when there's too much radiation for your suit to block, it slowly accumulates. Once it accumulates enough, you start to suffer radiation burns and/or sickness. If that happens, don't bother curing it, because you'll just immediately get sick again and have wasted your valuable item. In order to clean the radiation, you need to build a furniture (deco) block, enter the right click menu while placing it, and select one of the two showers. Taking a shower will clean the accumulated radiation. But nothing would tell you this unless you tried building decorative furniture, which is always at the top of my priority list when I'm dying of radiation poisoning.

-Pay attention to the tabs on the construction menus (or every menu, really). For some it's relatively obvious, but for others not so much. Of note, there are tabs at the top of the food processor to make medicine or seeds.

Lastly, some more general tips that would still be helpful even if the game didn't still feel like a beta.

-Finding resources on the planet's surface is time consuming and risky. As soon as you can, build a small vessel to take into space and start mining asteroids. You'll need a suit with an EVA Boost and a Drill with at least a couple Drill Charges. Use the scanner in space to find asteroids and fly around until you find one with Prometheum, then you can make all the Drill Charges you want to continue mining whatever else you find.

Go back into survival mode, open the blueprint library, then select your blueprint and click the 'To Factory' button. Incredible game, though it has some quirks and shortcomings, it is definitely worth your time.

The core of the game is the block building system. In between survival, combat and mining you'll be spending a lot of time choosing blocks to make a cool looking base and fleet of ships. Aesthetically, it's probably hands down the best sci-fi block building system around (Dual Universe is technologically superior and will probably surpass it at some point, but not yet). There's an amazing array of block shapes and many textures to choose from, so you're able to create some absolutely stunning space ships and stations if you put the work in. And if you don't have time, you can easily download from a HUGE selection of other people's creations on the game's steam workshop. There's some truly impressive work on there, make sure to have a look.

The block physics aren't quite as good. It doesn't have true moving parts like Space Engineers, although you do get a decent array of working components like lights, sensors, doors, shutters, ramps, docking feet and hangar bay doors. There's no collision damage on ships, however, so things are a bit comical at times.

The worlds are beautiful and interesting for the most part. There's a range of planet types each with a very distinctive look, although in the galaxy mode with 1000s of star systems it suffers from the No Man's Sky problem of things being very samey. But you really only need a handful of planets to keep you occupied for countless hours.

There's a decent array of creatures and races, though perhaps not quite enough, and they lack personality. It's not true what others have said that they are aimbots, although they are fairly accurate and especially without heavy armour you can die if you make a mistake very quick. Base turrets can waste unprepared ships very quickly too. But the enemies are mostly fairly easy to defeat once you work out the techniques. The AI is fairly basic and isn't very pro-active. The gunplay and survival elements are a little rudimentary overall, although it's still playable.

The resource gathering, mining, construction elements are great fun. There's a variety of ways to gather, with a good range of resources. The development team have published a lot of the configuration files for use, so there are currently a number of people tuning the game to their own tastes, and in some case publishing those changes for others. It's great to see how much the configuration options for the game have been opened up, even if there is little to no documentation.

Multiplayer is by far the most fun. Working together with others and seeing their weird and wonderful creations is epic. Building a base for the entire faction and then seeing everyone's ships parked around is very rewarding. PvP is also fun even if it is very janky and quite buggy. There is quite a lot of toxicity from a small section of the PvP community in the game, but PvP is easily avoided by joining a PvE focused server. The devs appear to have lost patience with this section of PvPers and have been neglecting PvP a lot recently, which is understandable but sad. PvP is definitely the most dynamic part of gameplay with the most potential if improved.

The community is super friendly (discord, forums), but I've found the dev team is a bit inaccessible. They tend to not comment on exploit reports or suggestions, they refuse to discuss directions, and they don't currently have any roadmap. Suggestions and feedback get no love, acknowledgement or even interaction most of the time, which is a mistake for a game where the community creation and feedback is supposedly so central. They're also terrible at community management at times, apparently struggling with knowing how to deal with toxic players. But it's a very small dev team (7-8 developers I think), so this is somewhat understandable. I hope they work on this area a little, because it's quite amazing what they've achieved otherwise.

The decision making process for changes and feature decisions is bizarre at times. Sometimes they seem to have made kneejerk decisions for a playerbase popularity stunt, at other times changes don't seem to have had any community input. I think they could benefit from spending more time talking to experienced players, content creators and server managers.

Still, there's a lot to do and if you like sci-fi and constructing things, this is for you.

All in all, this is an amazing purchase for it's price. If you've played Space Engineers, it's that, except with much better block selection, worse physics, similar though distinct graphics, and better survival elements. If you've never played a game like this before, think Minecraft in space for grown-ups. Flawed, but overall, incredible and worth a look.

I'm just going to start off simply:  If you want nothing more than "Space Legos"; that is, the ability to use blocks to build various ships and bases, but with otherwise very little point, then this is your game.  If you're looking for an indie game with plot and depth, akin to Subnautica (but in space):  you might want to look elsewhere - this one is simply not finished yet, and is in no way what I'd consider a "full featured game".   

That out of the way?  I really, REALLY wanted to love this game, but there's just not enough "meat and potatoes" here to really keep all but the most devoted players interested.  An immersive storyline?  That doesn't exist, here - and you're given a hastily thrown together (and unfinished) set of missions, complete with bad writing and bugs.  And bugs?  Oh, there's a lot of those, since this game is very much unfinished.  Right off the bat in the tutorial / early missions, there's numerous occasions where you can (and likely will) salvage various decorative consoles, only to find out that, whoopsie, the game wants to use that asset for a mission later, leaving you with a quest marker for an object that no longer exists.  

Animations and graphics are incredibly dated, and quite a lot of things are straight-up recycled unity assets.  I could fill an entire page with the various bugs I encountered, but a few include:
* Falling through the map
* Water is non-volumetric, which is sorta laughable in 2020.  This means if you dig a hole underneath a lake, it doesn't fill in.  Want a water feature in your base?  Not gonna happen.
* Enemy AI is non existent, and any ranged enemies basically have aimbot / will hit you as long as they have line of sight.  Their weapons are also way better than anything the player gets, meaning often the only way to successfully attack an enemy base is to resort to cheap tactics, essentially exploiting the game.

Once you manage to build yourself a ship to get off the starting planet, you will likely come to realize what I did, very quickly.  That is: the universe is vast and lifeless, and you quickly find yourself asking "What's next?".  The various empires are static, and don't have any interaction with the player aside from occasional attacks on your base.  The multitude of planets?  It's neat to check them out for the first time, but every single one is just a cookie cutter of the last; the same crashed ships to salvage, the same enemy bases that stay where they are, and no real reason for doing anything.  If you thought No Man's Sky was a lonely, lifeless universe filled with a ton of "same-y" planets, EGS may indeed take the cake.

Finally, the last note I want to make?  The community / devs are, at least from what I've seen, generally incredibly averse to any sort of criticism, and will outright attack and insult players for having a dissenting opinion on the game.  Have a concern about a major bug, or think that a feature is missing?  Oh-HO!   A small but loyal following will come out of the woodwork to scream about how many hours they've invested, and how anybody with more than 100 hours "got their money's worth and should stop complaining".   It's like buying a used car, putting 100 hours into repairing it as it constantly breaks down, and being told "Well, you clearly got your money's worth, you spend a lot of time with it!", while completely missing the point.  IE: that time spent doing something doesn't necessarily correlate to "enjoyment".  

TLDR: This is an alpha-grade project at best, and is not in any way what I would consider a "full game".  Tons of bugs, an unfinished and uninspiring main quest, a downright toxic community,  incredibly clunky UI / gameplay, and no real point to doing much, once you get a ship.  The survival aspects are pretty much "done" after the first 2 hours or so.  If all you want to do is use creative mode to build ships, but don't care about actual gameplay, story, or plot?  Have at it.  For everyone else, I'd suggest looking elsewhere.  Who knows, maybe in another 5 years, there'll be something worthwhile here, though I have my doubts.

I started replaying this with friends recently. It has potential, but is full of bugs, weird UI and game design, along with a completely unforgiving environment. 

As an example, I parked my ship outside a trading station and headed inside. 5 seconds later it gets attacked and completely cored out by a passing NPC ship. No problem, I'll salvage what I can and teleport back to my base. The teleport back put me 12km away from the station. No problem, I'll put something heavy on the 'W' key and come back in a while. On getting back... no ship, no station. No problem, I'll just restart the server. Salvage what's left of the ship. Oh, the cargo's completely empty for some reason? No problem, guess I just lost a bunch of stuff, oh well.

When I first played it, I built a simple hover vehicle, drove around for a couple of minutes exploring, then got one-shotted by a bunch of mobs with rocket launchers.

Game design is similarly weird. You can put turrets on hover vehicles, but not flying ships. There are a whole bunch of duplicate thrusters in the tech tree for some reason. Solar power doesn't work very well, and you're limited to 20 of them per base. Starting up, you'll get attacked non-stop by spiders and other weird creatures.

Pretty much everything in the game is half-assed. You can't capture enemy ships, just shoot all of their guns off, at which point they cartwheel around the planet like a strange cross between a whale and a tumbleweed. The economy is weirdly broken - you're better off building a bunch of crap like ore detectors, shotguns and chainsaws, then selling it to the local merchants for health packs and multitool charges, than building them by grinding/farming a whole bunch of parts. You can't build rep with factions by trading or taking over the bad guys bases, instead you'll need to murder a bunch of spiders in their territory. But fixed guns only; no turrets. Ship building is kinda fun, but the interface to cut+paste is so terrible that it's probably easier to just build it block by block in survival.

And so on and so on. There are some fun parts, but probably half the time I've spent playing has been working around or recovering from weird bugs or jank. If you can get it on sale and play it with friends it's probably good value for money, but don't expect a fun single player experience.

It can be hard to review a game that's still in development, because while you're reviewing what's already there, you're also reviewing the game's *potential*, and Empyrion has a lot of potential.

Currently, it's definitely one of my favourite Minecraft-esques, it has just enough simulationism to force you to think a bit when building stuff, but not so much that you waste hours deciding where a single wire goes or that the whole thing becomes a slog. It also has a bunch of cosmetic stuff implemented at base that other games never even consider allowing you.

On top of that, while building to build is a nice enough motivation, Empyrion also goes a lot towards what you build being useful, since you're encouraged from an early stage to raid hostile bases("Points of Interest") for materials and resources that may be a tier above what you already have easy access to, as well as to stop the faction(s) you choose to be hostile to, from raiding you(a classic feature of Empyrion is that your first base will receive visits from Zirax raider squads, one of their bases on the planet you're on is host to the raiders, and thus teching up to take it out becomes your first long-term goal, requiring that you get some good guns and armor and also build some hardy combat vehicles since it'll have hefty turret defenses on the outside).

In addition, Empyrion has some gorgeous graphical details in places. While the enemy models aren't all that amazing, nor, in fact, many of the environmental models, there's just something about the lighting engine that really works. The combination between the music(which is quite good) and the lighting just makes surface exploration feel oddly satisfying.

It's also a game that gets a lot of love from the developer, there's always been something in the works on the game for as long as I've owned it, and while it's not always been stuff that's immediately affected the gameplay, they haven't been afraid to get their hands dirty with fundamental under-the-hood revamps to make the game run smoother or allow future improvements without the game grinding to a screeching, smoking halt.

Like all such games, though, the big caveat is: do you have someone to play with? Singleplayer just isn't going to be satisfying. But that's not really a point against Empyrion, it's just a feature of the genre, and something to keep in mind.

Currently, the thing to keep an eye out for is Empyrion revamping its progression system and on-foot combat, since they're the only ones who can, in the late-ish game, feel a bit lacking. Eventually you'll have unlocked everything you can build, and the enemy infantry combat AI is a bit... shallow. But I have confidence that it's coming, sooner or later.

One of my favorite games for use as a creative outlet.  It's a very gritty and raw sci-fi themed survival/building sim that let's you build buildings, hover crafts, star fighters and capital ships capable of warping to nearby planets within the procedurally generated star system. 

Survival mode can be challenging and requires a lot of exploring and grinding to collect materials, which can be fun if you're into that sort of challenge. However it takes a lot of time to be able to build the big stuff, which means setting up sprawling networks of autominers and constantly running around collecting them. Once you get to that point, you've basically beaten survival mode and them the question falls to what do you want to build and where do you want to build it?

You can also jump straight to the building aspect with creative mode or the itemmenu catalog. There are some really impressive blueprints that people have created in the workshop, as well. 

***ISSUES***

The big downside is the lack of support for mission immersion. The in-game "missions" are just lame text boxes that nobody wants to read and you can actually turn them off because the devs know the missions are super lame or really... non-existent. They put very little into making it feel more real or at the very least, more like an adventure. The game is very stoic in that it is purely survival. There are no animations, cinematics, cutscenes or even just pictures to add to the story. You do not interact with other beings and no creature ever speaks a word. 

Your allies don't help you with anything and your enemies are obnoxiously weak at attacking your base. The only benefit to having an ally is that you can use their shops. But they have no ships and no troops, only buildings and land. 

Now personally, I enjoy building a stronghold and defending it from wave after wave of attacks in my survival games. Last time I found scenario with an ultra-hard planet and I built my base on top of a mountain, right next to a shielded enemy drone base, in their territory. Base attack level 10 with unlimited attacks. Still too easy. They could never land a single troop transport. 

If the transports would land outside of range and then they come in on foot it would make more sense. Attacks also only come from one direction each time. They never flank you. Then there is the lack of diversity in how you can be attacked. The enemy only has dropships and drones. There is the occasional capital ship seen wandering around. When it's working correctly, you can knock it out quickly with a competent SV. 

However there are no HVs or SVs to battle in survival mode, although I do understand why. The devs do not prioritize AI in any way. All the NPCs are super basic. These devs seem to prioritize reflections on textures and screen flares from the sun ahead of playability and immersion. The reflections are still really buggy too. 

***PERFORMANCE***

I'm hoping the performance improves with the next big update because it seems to have problems utilizing system resources. I have a liquid cooled custom built rig and it still has performance problems with large POIs or areas with lots of POIs grouped together. I feel like the game doesn't cache data as well as it should. The distance of view is also choppy. I hate it when a large building just appears out of nowhere because it wasn't preloaded correctly. You could be standing on a mountain looking down into a valley and have no idea there are buildings there, even with maxed settings. 

*******VERDICT*******

Empyrion is a fantastic game with loads of potential but is great as a survival builder in it's current form. It may not be perfect but it's the best that I've seen so far in this particular genre. I play it all the time, bugs and all. On my last survival game I found an ocean planet and built a naval base to launch a fleet of hover craft warships. I built a battleship with 3 variants along with an aircraft carrier loaded with fighters. They turned out awesome!

Early Access Review (Not A12E)

Empyrion is a building, light survival, exploration, murder hobo game. Well, you can build a base, and not be a hobo, but since you'll need to travel to other planets or systems for resources, you're pretty much a space murder hobo. 

If you like building within a framework of rules this game is for you! There isn't anything too complicated about most of the building, in that blocks are assumed to have power wires going through them. You still need to manage things like CPU (how many things the computers can control) and weight (Yeah, you can build a ship that holds 8 million tons, but you better have the thrusters to lift it). 

The Good:
Creativity to build all kinds of things. A base, check! A horrible motor cycle that is faster than walking, check! A little (or big) ground vehicle, check! A futuristic hover tank, check! An airplane, check! A space ship, check! A large capitol wessel to carry all the other stuff in, check! An orbital space station to park your carrier, check! Defend a raid on your base(s), check! Attack other bases, check! Loot, check! Horrible space diseases that will kill you if not treated, check!

The bad:
Combat and AI are a little weak. Hit boxes are a little janky. Very small weapon selection (pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, minigun, rocket launcher, laser rifle with 2-3 tiers of each). Only 5 armors (none, light, medium, heavy, epic). Weak RPG elements, and character progression.

The Ugly:
Graphics. Its a pretty ugly game, some things have been improved though.

The Unknown:
I've not indulged in PvP yet. With the janky hit boxes, and fact that someone will be able to put in hundreds more hours than me, my pea shooter is probably not going to hold up well against someone else's fully armed and operational battle station. 

The only game I can really compare this to is 7D2D, and we all know how fantastic that game has become. This is like space 7D2D without a set horde schedule.

This game is still early access of course, but the improvements I really like. The addition of CPU, and weight+volumes I really like! This addition has really played havoc with the workshop, but gives a sense of progression. You can't just go from a space loincloth and space club to the Aluminum Falcon any more. 

The missions and quests are a little weak, but I understand the devs are working on it. The first solo mission chain is AMAZING (to me, if played as intended). It reminds me of Aliens. 

The game still has a ways to go, but with the galaxy opening up soon I'm really looking forward to a nearly limitless area to explore instead of around 20ish "systems." 

I'd really like to see some RPG elements added and a different character progression. Maybe something like more "specialized" skill trees. For instance, you could build the most amazing hover tank(HV) ever! But, your small ships (SV) and capitol vessels(CV) are only ok. It would give people a better reason to band together in multi-player. 

The factory system is handy, but also should be tweaked. You can literally build any creation as long as the size class is supported by your server/game and have the level. I think this is a little over powered. I'd like to see something more along the lines of a physical factory facility you have to build. Lowest tier gives you access to your own creations, then one for workshop hover vehicles, another for small vessels, a fourth for capitol vessels, and a final one for workshop bases. Or even split bases into terrestrial and space. What you have access to should be limited by your skills, or pay credits(in addition to resources) for what you don't know. Maybe make NPC factory POI's (point of interest). So you have to go make friends with one of the alien races to use their factory to build that shiny new jrandall creation. 

I really like where this game is heading. Sure, some of the people who have been playing it longer than I are upset by some of the changes (CPU, Weights+Volumes) You can turn those features off, and build without those limitations.

CPU feature: Basically, the "computer" of your base, hover vessel, small vessel, or capitol vessel is now limited on what it can control. All the items you add have a value that count against the CPU value. Your creation will have decreased effectiveness if you exceed the CPU rating.

Weight+Volume: Basically its like this. If you put a bunch of heavy rocks in your vehicle, you need to have the power to lift and push it. Volume is like trying to put a bed in a shoe box. 

I say get this game, and join the rest of us on its development journey!

Yes. Very much yes. Of all space survival/exploration/crafting games, Empyrion is my favorite by far. 

Is it perfect? Certainly not. The game is being developed by a small indy developer and it shows. At the time of writing, it's unpolished, to say the least: combat is quirky, performance so-so, NPC and character modeling is rudimentary at best, water acts weirds... the list goes on. 

But in exchange for coping with that, you'll get a game of a scope and depth you won't find anywhere else. Explore the universe. Fly to any planet and land on it. Interact with the locals. Build bases and fully functional spaceships from scratch, using an intuitive crafting system that allows for enormous variety. Save your creations as blueprints and share them via Steam, or download and use one of the thousands designs other players made. 

Almost everything in the game world can be modified: you can raise or lower terrain, build underground or under water, take over NPC bases and demolish them or alternatively, tailor them to your own needs. There are many Points of Interest to explore, ranging from derelict spaceships to ancient alien facilities. The game also caters to various play styles: you can befriend alien factions and trade with them, or go on a rampage and conquer the known galaxy. The universe is yours.

Another good thing: the team is still actively developing the game. So expect more quality-of-life improvement and possibly new features as well in the months/years to come.

As with any other survival game, Empyrion has a learning curve. If you're playing for the first time, surviving and dealing with aggressive aliens may provide some challenge and certainly will require a bit of grind. But believe me, it's doable and totally worth it once you get the hang of it.

73954275.review:
This is an amazing space game that deserves more attention from players.

It recently left alpha development to 1.0, and although it remains rough around the edges, the game has so many strings to its bow. 

For example, there is a survival-type start on a planet where you begin with nothing and need to struggle to establish a defensible base. Then you build hover vessels or flying small vessels to explore the planet. Leaving the planet and entering space for the first time is an emotional experience. The local solar system can be explored, and with time, large capital vessels can be made to explore the galaxy. 

This game is special because, like Avorion, the player designs their buildings and ships block-by-block and the creative freedom is liberating. I understand that games like No-Man's-Sky and Elite Dangerous do not allow the player to design their own ships and I view this as a serious limitation. Ships you make in Empyrion must also be functional and so design and function come together in a thoughtful way. This game has sufficient first person shooter elements and when attacking various enemy bases or ships there is loot to be found. The game is packed with different mechanics such as food production via farming, oxygenation of your bases or ships, fuel management, shields, computing power, weights and volumes and more and your experience can be tailored via the difficulty settings. 

Several times my ship was shot down unexpectedly on distant moons and I was faced with the prospect of repairing my ship under hostile conditions. These were some of the best gaming moments I have had. Of course, successfully raiding a difficult Zirax base is satisfying too. There is a learning curve in Empyrion but between the built-in PDA information and public forums i was fine. Games without learning curves are made for 8 year old children anyway right?

My top three under-rated games on steam would be this: Empyrion Galactic Survival, Supreme Commander Forged Alliance Forever, and Crosscode. 

I think the developers will continue to make Empyrion better and I highly recommend it.

Here's an example of how things are in the game and the devs' response to them-

There is Workshop support, and you can import/export blueprints for use in the game. 
The Factory interface for using Workshop blueprints only lists the requirements for building at the most basic level - ie 450 Iron Ingots needed.

You can reduce the Factory build time by inputting more complex components instead, say Steel Sheets instead of Iron Ingots, but the Blueprints and Factory don't give you any indication of how many Steel Sheets are needed, just the raw Iron Ingots number. 
So it's something less than 450 but you don't know how many it is. You also have no indication if the more complex items will or won't qualify for the required raw materials in the blueprint. 

Additionally, the Factory cannot return items input into it, at all. So if you put 10 extra Steel Sheets in the Factory, or an item that doesn't actually work in that blueprint, they're in there forever until a later blueprint uses them, you cannot get them back. This is a design oversight that the devs have not figured out a solution to. 

And it's been like this for YEARS. And they released out of Early Access like this. 

If you're okay with this kind of situation in '1.0 release software', go nuts and buy it. 
If you're not, be aware ahead of time.
